articles.title: AUGUST 1986
articles.summary: This document outlines the astronomical and organizational activities for August and September 1986, primarily focusing on field expeditions for observation, board and general meetings, and introductory astronomy classes. A notable event scheduled for August 23rd is a general meeting featuring Space Shuttle Astronaut Dr. Lorin Acton, who flew aboard Challenger on the Space Lab I mission. The schedule also includes indoor star parties and educational programs.

articles.title: ASTRONAUT LORIX ACTON TO SPEAK AUGUST 30TH
articles.summary: Dr. Lorin Acton, a Space Shuttle Astronaut, is scheduled to speak at the San Jose Astronomical Association's General Meeting on August 30th at 8 PM. This event offers a unique opportunity to meet an astronaut, particularly significant in the wake of the Challenger disaster. A record turnout is anticipated, and attendees are advised to arrive early and consider carpooling due to limited parking.

articles.title: DE ANZA PLANETARIUM OPEMIMG
articles.summary: The De Anza Planetarium is holding a re-opening event on the evening of September 5th and is inviting San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) members to bring their telescopes for the occasion. Interested members are asked to contact Tom Ahl for further details and to participate.

articles.title: GLACIER POINT RECAP
articles.summary: A field expedition for astronomical observations to Glacier Point on July 4/5th was highly successful, despite initial concerns about crowds and a recent forest fire. Participants enjoyed steady, clear, and dark skies at Yosemite, observing fine details in Saturn's rings and the majestic Milky Way. Special thanks were extended to Jim Baumgardt for his excellent slide shows.

articles.title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
articles.summary: This "Letters to the Editor" section addresses several member communications. One letter advocates for the inclusion of Isaac Asimov in a list of scientifically accurate science fiction authors, citing his background and extensive works. Other letters discuss practical club matters, including a member's complaint about missing issues of "The Ephemeris" newsletter (attributed to mailing list errors and a double issue) and a suggestion for a monthly president's message detailing events and business, which the editor supports.

articles.title: By: JAY REYNOLDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: Jay Reynolds Freeman highlights the exceptional astrophotography work of his friend, professional photographer Ctein, who used the dye transfer process to create remarkable color prints of Comet Halley. Despite using amateur equipment and facing difficult conditions, Ctein produced prints with superior dynamic range and precise color, allowing for unprecedented detail in both bright and faint celestial features. The article advocates for the wider adoption of this overlooked printing technique to enhance astronomical photography.

articles.title: JUPITER'S GREAT RED SPOT
articles.summary: Jupiter is favorably positioned for observation as it approaches opposition, making it an excellent time for observers to begin a dedicated program, especially given its good placement for the next several years. The article details specific satellite eclipses and shadow transits for August, including an event with the Red Spot. A comprehensive table provides dates and times for viewing the Great Red Spot on the meridian from early August to early September (PDT).

articles.title: THE 1986 PERSEID METEOR SHOWER BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article details the upcoming 1986 Perseid Meteor Shower, predicting its peak on August 12 with up to sixty meteors per hour and favorable dark sky conditions. It offers tips for observing and photography, discusses the unobserved Comet Swift-Tuttle, and reviews past Perseid activity. The piece also briefly mentions the "Aries Flasher" and other concurrent meteor showers like the Delta Aquarids and iota Aquarids.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article, "COMET COMMENTS BY DON MACHHOLZ," reports that no bright comets are currently visible, with Halley's Comet out of sight and Comet Machholz having dimmed. It details the recovery of two faint periodic comets, Holmes (mag. 18) and Forbes (mag. 20.5), by J. Gibson. The piece also mentions the Solwind satellite's 1983 observation of a sixth sungrazing comet (1983 XX) crashing into the sun, which was not visible from Earth.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND -- HALLEY
articles.summary: This article provides an observational retrospective of Halley's Comet's latest return from July 1985 through April 1986, detailing its changing magnitude, appearance, and visibility conditions for amateur astronomers. It notes the comet's general fainter-than-predicted brightness but highlights moments of naked-eye visibility and tail development. The author also mentions that Halley's Comet will re-emerge into the morning sky in November 1986 after being obscured by the sun's glare.

articles.title: BY: ROBERT FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article details significant delays in NASA's Space Shuttle program until 1988 for redesign and testing, along with the cancellation of the Shuttle/Centaur upper stage, impacting planetary missions like Galileo and Ulysses. It also covers the identification of a Delta rocket failure's cause, ESA's approval of the Hermes mini-shuttle, and the planned resumption of Ariane launches in early 1987. Furthermore, 1991 has been designated as an International Space Year, and observations of Halley's Comet are noted through May 1986.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA hosts monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, fostering a friendly environment for members to discuss various astronomical interests like astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making. These meetings occur on the 4th Saturday of each month, starting at 8 PM, with detailed directions provided for attendees.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The article describes monthly "Indoor Star Parties" which are informal gatherings for amateur astronomy enthusiasts, open to both members and non-members. These events feature telescope sharing, astrophotography slideshows, and an introductory astronomy workshop, often alongside the SJAA's board meetings. They serve as a social occasion for sharing interests and fostering community within the amateur astronomy scene.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to a specific observing site within Henry Coe State Park, accessible via Hwy 101 South and the East Dunne exit. It includes crucial logistical information such as the gate combination (4585), instructions for locking the gate, and advice for parking if arriving after dark. The site is noted as a location where the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) sets up equipment.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is highlighted as a 3000 ft elevated astronomical observing site, frequently used by the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) for star parties at Coulter Camp during clear new moon weekends. The article provides detailed driving directions to the park, advises early arrival due to the common presence of 30-40 telescopes, and includes information about the SJAA's "Ephemeris" publication and its organizational leadership.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership types and corresponding fees, including options for Membership Only, Membership with Sky & Telescope subscription, and Junior membership. The form requests personal contact information and provides instructions for submission either at an SJAA meeting or by mail to the treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document contains an optional questionnaire from a non-profit organization, likely the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), designed to gather information on members' astronomical interests, telescope ownership, and areas of expertise. It appears to be part of a mailing, indicated by the postage and "NEWS MATERIAL" labels, aimed at understanding and engaging its community.
